title: 114_hr3295
content: The Department of Justice's Office of Justice Programs is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance in fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, focusing on public health approaches to reduce shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes. $15,000,000 is allocated for competitive grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in States with high rates of primary treatment admissions for heroin and other opioids for investigative purposes related to illicit activities and trafficking. The Small Business Administration receives additional funding for entrepreneurial development programs and business loans. The Department of Labor receives extra funding for training and employment services. The Department of Health and Human Services receives funding for maternal and child health programs. The Department of Health and Human Services receives additional funding for maternal and child health programs, substance abuse treatment, and the Healthy Start Initiative. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives funding for Public and Indian Housing. The Department of Health and Human Services receives additional funding for substance abuse treatment. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives funding for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative and community development fund. The Community Development Fund receives an additional $500,000,000 for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas impacted by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments based on criteria determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can grant funds to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to recover from events based on specific criteria like racial or income segregation, low employment rates, poor-performing schools, infant mortality, vacant homes, and proximity to hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage and eligibility criteria for approval before receiving funds. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can provide funds to distressed communities near hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan for fund usage approval within 45 days of enactment. Funds allocated are separate from non-emergency formula allocations. The Secretary may disapprove plans that do not meet criteria. Funds under this heading are not relevant to non-emergency formula allocations. Grantees must receive training on grant management and include performance requirements in contracts. The Secretary can waive provisions of statutes or regulations when administering funds. The Secretary has the authority to waive provisions of statutes or regulations when administering funds for contracts or subrecipient agreements, except for certain requirements. Up to 30 percent of the funds can be used for technical assistance to provide immediate community response. The Secretary may use up to 30 percent of funds for technical assistance to provide immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for necessary costs of administering and overseeing funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028 with the same terms, except for mutually agreed changes. Agencies must report financial data to measure policy effects. The Act designates each amount as an emergency requirement and will only be available if the President designates and transmits all amounts to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
